qas.question: Which two Spaniards aided this colonization and started the first catholic church?

answers.text: Diego Luis de San Vitores and Pedro Calungsod

qas.question: When did Guam's Cathedral first open?
What was the name of the first Cathedral?
In what year did Spain colonize Mexico City?
What was Pedro Calungsod's Catholic church named?
On what date did Spain colonize the Philippines?
On what date was the Governor's Palace in Plaza de Espana completed?
Who had the Royal College of San Juan de Letran built?

context: Spanish colonization commenced on <a0_0><b6_0>June 15, <b4_0>1668<b6_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> with the arrival of <a1_0><b8_0>Diego Luis de San Vitores<b8_0/> and Pedro Calungsod<a1_0/>, who established the first Catholic church.:64 The islands were part of the Spanish East Indies governed from the Philippines, which were in turn part of the Viceroyalty of New Spain based in Mexico City. Other reminders of colonial times include the old Governor's Palace in Plaza de España and the Spanish Bridge, both in Hagatña. Guam's <b5_0>Cathedral <a3_0>Dulce Nombre de Maria<b5_0/><a3_0/> was formally opened on <a2_0><b7_0>February 2, 1669<b7_0/><a2_0/>, as was the Royal College of San Juan de Letran.:68 Guam, along with the rest of the Mariana and Caroline Islands, were treated as part of Spain's colony in the Philippines. While Guam's Chamorro culture has indigenous roots, the cultures of both Guam and the Northern Marianas have many similarities with Spanish and Mexican culture due to three centuries of Spanish rule.
